canonical_explanation.text: Data can be represented visually using graphs. A bar graph uses rectangular bars of equal width to represent data — the height of each bar shows the frequency. A pictograph uses pictures or symbols to represent data — each symbol represents a certain number of items (the key). A line graph shows data points connected by lines, useful for showing change over time. All graphs need a title, labelled axes, and a scale.
rules: Bar graph: bars of equal width, height shows frequency
Bar graphs need: title, x-axis label, y-axis label, scale
Pictograph: pictures/symbols represent data, needs a key
Key in pictograph tells how many items each symbol represents
Line graph: data points joined by straight lines
Line graphs show how data changes over time
Always choose an appropriate scale for the axes

questions.question_text: In a bar graph, data is represented using:
questions.explanation_correct: A bar graph uses rectangular bars to represent data.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Bar graph = rectangular bars of equal width.

questions.question_text: In a bar graph, what does the height of each bar represent?

options.text: The frequency or value of the data

questions.explanation_correct: The height (or length) of each bar shows the frequency or value of that category.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Bar height = frequency (count) for that category.

questions.question_text: In a pictograph, data is represented using:
questions.explanation_correct: A pictograph uses pictures or symbols to represent data values.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Pictograph = pictures/symbols to show data.

questions.question_text: A pictograph shows a key: Each star = 5 students. If 'Cricket' has 4 stars, how many students like cricket?
questions.explanation_correct: 4 stars × 5 students per star = 20 students.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 4 × 5 = 20 students like cricket.

questions.question_text: A line graph is best for showing:
questions.explanation_correct: Line graphs are ideal for showing how data changes over time (trends).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Line graphs show trends and changes over time.

questions.question_text: In a bar graph, all bars must have equal width.
questions.explanation_correct: In a bar graph, bars have equal width; only the height varies to show different values.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Bar width is constant. Only height changes to show data.

questions.question_text: A bar graph shows: Mango-15, Apple-10, Banana-20, Grapes-5. Which fruit is most popular?
questions.explanation_correct: Banana has the tallest bar (20), making it the most popular.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Banana (20) has the highest frequency/tallest bar.

questions.question_text: In the same bar graph, the difference between the most and least popular fruits is:
questions.explanation_correct: Most popular: Banana (20). Least popular: Grapes (5). Difference = 20 - 5 = 15.

questions.question_text: In a pictograph, each smiley = 10 students. 'Football' shows 3 smileys and a half smiley. How many like football?
questions.explanation_correct: 3 full smileys = 30. Half smiley = 5. Total = 35 students.

questions.question_text: In a pictograph with key: 1 apple symbol = 4 baskets. If a farmer sold 20 baskets of apples, how many symbols should be drawn?
questions.explanation_correct: 20 ÷ 4 = 5 symbols.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 20 baskets ÷ 4 per symbol = 5 symbols.

questions.question_text: A line graph shows temperature: Mon-30°C, Tue-32°C, Wed-35°C, Thu-33°C, Fri-28°C. On which day was it hottest?
questions.explanation_correct: Wednesday had the highest temperature at 35°C (the highest point on the line graph).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Wednesday (35°C) is the peak temperature.

questions.question_text: When drawing a bar graph, the scale on the y-axis should be:
questions.explanation_correct: The y-axis scale must have equal intervals (e.g., 0, 5, 10, 15, 20...) for accurate representation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Equal intervals ensure the bars correctly represent the data.

questions.question_text: A bar graph has y-axis scale: 0, 10, 20, 30, 40. A bar reaches halfway between 20 and 30. The value is:
questions.explanation_correct: Halfway between 20 and 30 = (20+30)/2 = 25.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Midpoint of 20 and 30 = 25.

questions.question_text: A pictograph key says: 1 book symbol = 2 books. If a student read 7 books, how should this be shown?
questions.explanation_correct: 7 ÷ 2 = 3.5 = 3 full symbols and half a symbol.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 7 books ÷ 2 per symbol = 3.5 symbols = 3 full + 1 half.

questions.question_text: In a line graph showing plant growth over 5 weeks, if the line goes up from Week 1 to Week 3, this means:
questions.explanation_correct: An upward line on a line graph means the value is increasing — the plant is growing.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Line going up = value increasing = plant growing.

questions.question_text: Every bar graph needs:
questions.explanation_correct: A bar graph needs a title, labels on both axes, a scale, and the bars.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Essential parts: title, x-axis label, y-axis label, scale, and bars.

questions.question_text: In a bar graph, the x-axis usually shows the ___ and the y-axis shows the ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The x-axis typically shows categories (items being compared) and the y-axis shows the frequency or values.
questions.explanation_incorrect: X-axis = categories, Y-axis = frequency/values.

questions.question_text: What is the 'key' or 'legend' in a pictograph?

options.text: It tells what each symbol represents

questions.explanation_correct: The key/legend tells how many items each symbol in the pictograph represents.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Key/legend explains what each picture symbol stands for.

questions.question_text: A line graph shows sales: Jan-100, Feb-150, Mar-130, Apr-200, May-180. In which month did sales drop compared to the previous month?
questions.explanation_correct: March (130) dropped from February (150). May (180) dropped from April (200). Both had drops.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Feb→Mar: 150→130 (drop). Apr→May: 200→180 (drop). Both months showed decline.

questions.question_text: In a bar graph, bars can overlap each other.
questions.explanation_correct: In a standard bar graph, bars are separate with equal gaps between them. They do not overlap.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Bars in a bar graph are separate, not overlapping.

questions.question_text: A pictograph uses circles. Key: 1 circle = 8 items. Category A has 3 circles. How many items?
questions.explanation_correct: 3 circles × 8 items per circle = 24 items.

questions.question_text: Which scale is best for a bar graph showing data: 12, 25, 18, 30, 22?
questions.explanation_correct: Scale of 5 (0, 5, 10, 15, 20, 25, 30) fits the data range (12-30) well and is easy to read.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Scale of 5 suits data ranging from 12 to 30. Not too compressed, not too spread out.

questions.question_text: In a line graph, what connects the data points?
questions.explanation_correct: In a line graph, consecutive data points are connected by straight lines.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Data points in a line graph are connected by straight lines.

questions.question_text: In a pictograph, 1 car symbol = 10 cars. A dealer sold 45 cars. How should this be shown?

options.text: 4 car symbols and half a car symbol

questions.explanation_correct: 45 ÷ 10 = 4.5 = 4 full symbols and half a symbol.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 45 ÷ 10 = 4.5 = 4 full + 1 half symbol.

questions.question_text: A horizontal bar graph has categories on the ___ and values on the ___:
questions.explanation_correct: In a horizontal bar graph, categories are on the y-axis and values are on the x-axis (bars go sideways).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Horizontal bar graph: categories on y-axis, values on x-axis.

questions.question_text: A line graph is suitable for showing favourite ice cream flavours.
questions.explanation_correct: Ice cream flavours are categories (not time-based). A bar graph or pictograph would be better. Line graphs are for data that changes over time.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Line graphs show change over time. For categories, use bar graphs.

questions.question_text: A bar graph shows students absent each day: Mon-3, Tue-5, Wed-2, Thu-7, Fri-4. Total absences in the week:
questions.explanation_correct: 3 + 5 + 2 + 7 + 4 = 21 total absences.

questions.question_text: In a pictograph, if 1 tree symbol = 5 trees and there are 6 symbols, the total is ___ trees.
questions.explanation_correct: 6 × 5 = 30 trees.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 6 symbols × 5 = 30 trees.

questions.question_text: Which graph would best show the number of students in each class of a school?
questions.explanation_correct: A bar graph is ideal for comparing quantities across different categories (classes).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Bar graphs are best for comparing quantities across categories.

questions.question_text: A line graph shows a student's marks: Test 1-60, Test 2-70, Test 3-65, Test 4-80, Test 5-90. The overall trend is:
questions.explanation_correct: Overall, marks went from 60 to 90 — an increasing trend (even though Test 3 dipped slightly).
questions.explanation_incorrect: 60→70→65→80→90. Despite a small dip at Test 3, the overall trend is upward.

questions.question_text: The gap between bars in a bar graph should be:
questions.explanation_correct: The gaps between bars should be uniform (equal) throughout the graph.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Consistent equal gaps make the bar graph neat and readable.

questions.question_text: Why might a pictograph use each symbol = 10 instead of each symbol = 1?

options.text: To make drawing easier when numbers are large
To make the data look bigger

questions.explanation_correct: When data values are large, using a larger key value (like 10) means fewer symbols to draw.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Large data values would need too many symbols if key = 1. Larger key = fewer symbols = easier to draw.

questions.question_text: A line graph shows flat (horizontal) line from March to May. This means:
questions.explanation_correct: A flat horizontal line means the value remained constant (no change).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Flat line = no change = constant value.

questions.question_text: A bar graph can have both vertical and horizontal bars.
questions.explanation_correct: Bar graphs can be vertical (bars going up) or horizontal (bars going sideways). Both are valid.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Both vertical and horizontal bar graphs exist.

questions.question_text: Pictograph key: 1 flower = 4 plants. Roses: 6 flowers, Lilies: 3 flowers, Tulips: 5 flowers. Total plants:
If the tallest bar in a bar graph reaches 45 on the y-axis, a good maximum value for the y-axis is:
questions.explanation_correct: The y-axis should extend slightly beyond the largest value. 50 is the nearest round number above 45.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Max data = 45. Y-axis max = 50 (round number slightly above data max).

questions.question_text: Which shows the steepest increase: a line going from 10 to 20, or from 10 to 50 (over the same time)?
questions.explanation_correct: A jump from 10 to 50 is a larger increase (40 units) than 10 to 20 (10 units), so the line is steeper.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 10→50 (increase of 40) is steeper than 10→20 (increase of 10).

questions.question_text: A bar graph uses ___ bars to represent data.
questions.explanation_correct: Bar graphs use rectangular bars of equal width.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Bar graph = rectangular bars.

questions.question_text: A pictograph shows half a symbol for a category. If 1 symbol = 6, the half symbol represents:
questions.explanation_correct: Half of 6 = 3. A half symbol represents half the key value.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Half symbol = half of key value = 6 ÷ 2 = 3.

questions.question_text: Which type of graph would best show the temperature of a city over 7 days?
questions.explanation_correct: Temperature over 7 days is data changing over time — perfect for a line graph.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Data over time = line graph.

questions.question_text: Bar graph data: Science-30, Maths-40, English-25, Hindi-35. The two subjects with the least combined students:
questions.explanation_correct: Science (30) + English (25) = 55, which is the smallest sum among the options.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 30 + 25 = 55 is the smallest combined total.

questions.question_text: A pictograph must always use the key value of 1 symbol = 1 item.
questions.explanation_correct: The key can be any suitable number (1, 2, 5, 10, etc.) depending on the data range.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Key value depends on the data. For large numbers, use key = 5, 10, etc.

questions.question_text: The title of a bar graph tells us:
questions.explanation_correct: The title describes what data the bar graph represents.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Title = what the graph is about (e.g., 'Favourite Fruits of Class 5').

questions.question_text: A line graph shows plant height: Week 1-2cm, Week 2-5cm, Week 3-9cm, Week 4-14cm. What does the steep upward line suggest?
questions.explanation_correct: A steep upward line indicates rapid growth — the plant height is increasing quickly.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Steep upward line = fast increase = rapid growth.

questions.question_text: If the y-axis scale is 0, 2, 4, 6, 8, 10, and a bar is at 7, where would it be?
questions.explanation_correct: 7 is exactly halfway between 6 and 8 on this scale.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 7 is the midpoint of 6 and 8.

questions.question_text: In a pictograph with key = 1 symbol = 100, to show 350 we need ___ full symbols and ___ half symbol.
questions.explanation_correct: 350 ÷ 100 = 3.5 = 3 full + 1 half symbol.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 350 = 3 × 100 + 50 = 3 full symbols + half a symbol.

questions.question_text: In a line graph, each data point is plotted using its x and y values.
questions.explanation_correct: Each data point has an x-value (e.g., month) and y-value (e.g., temperature), which determines where the dot is placed.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Points are plotted at the intersection of x and y values, then connected with lines.

questions.question_text: Which is NOT needed in a bar graph?
questions.explanation_correct: Bar graphs use bars, not pictures. Pictures are used in pictographs.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Bar graphs don't use pictures — that's a pictograph.

questions.question_text: A pictograph for 'Number of bicycles sold' uses a bicycle symbol. Key: 1 symbol = 20. Week 1: 3 symbols, Week 2: 5 symbols. How many more bicycles were sold in Week 2?
questions.explanation_incorrect: Difference = (5-3) × 20 = 2 × 20 = 40 more bicycles.

questions.question_text: A line graph showing monthly rainfall would have:

options.text: Months on x-axis, rainfall (mm) on y-axis
Rainfall on x-axis, months on y-axis

questions.explanation_correct: Months (time) go on the x-axis and rainfall amounts go on the y-axis.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Time (months) on x-axis, value (rainfall) on y-axis.
